Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Animal Care Culture in US Zoological Facilities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This ethnographic study will examine scientific and ethical practices involved in caring for and rehabilitating of animals in zoological facilities in the United States. It will employ participant observation, in-depth interviews, and archival research to explore how ideas about care and rehabilitation - including which animals can be sheltered and how best to determine and meet their needs - shape human-animal interactions and how these ideas and interactions have changed over time. Ethnographic research will take place in three private, non-profit zoological facilities.

This project will build on a growing body of work on multispecies ethnographies in anthropology and in other disciplines that seeks to illuminate how human-animal interactions in a range of scientific and applied contexts shape human understandings of animals and multispecies relationships.

This project will contribute to the training of a graduate student in anthropology. In addition, the resulting Ph.D. dissertation, articles, and public presentations will inform a deeper understanding of the ethics of animal treatment in contemporary US society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This ethnographic study examined the practices involved in caring for animals in zoological facilities in the United States. It employed participant observation, in-depth interviews, and archival research to explore how ideas about care and rehabilitation - including which animals can be sheltered and how best to determine and meet their needs - shape human-animal interactions and how these ideas and interactions have changed over time. Specifically, it collected data on the development and refinement of strategies for improving the physical and psychological health of captive animals relevant to a range of social settings in which humans interact with animals. Ethnographic research took place in three private, non-profit zoological facilities. 

Humans and animals are interacting in new ways as humans seek to create more humane environments for animal care.  This study explores what happens in those environments – whether or not animals flourish in them, in what ways animals pose dangers to humans, how adaptable animals are to new zoological environments that are more naturalistic, and what impact humans have on animals in these environments. This project has provided valuable professional training to a graduate student in anthropology, who has presented the findings at several conferences and is contributing a chapter to a forthcoming book on animals and the law. In addition, the resulting Ph.D. dissertation and further articles and public presentations will educate the public about novel developments in the evolving field of animal care in the United States.

The study found that research sites face a range of challenges in caring for animals. Findings indicate that many animals experience stress when placed in new zoological environments and that they may act out aggressively toward humans or other animals. In order to minimize this stress, caregivers  house animals in enclosures that approximate their natural environments. When interacting with these animals, caregivers also mimic their postures and movements so as not to be perceived as threats. Conditions of captivity can also cause health issues for certain animals. Caregivers have developed specialized veterinary techniques to address these issues, including formulating grain mixtures that meet the unique nutritional needs of particular species, devising new methods for preventing the spread of parasites, and designing structures and equipment that allow animals to engage in physical exercise.  In working through these challenges, caregivers at these facilities are devising new ways of caring for animals that minimize risk for workers, volunteers, and visitors while maximizing the potential for animals to thrive.
